tit.cmt: 用語集にあわせました。

sen.j: 玄昉（げんぼう、? - 天平18年6月18日 (旧暦)（746年7月15日））は、奈良時代の法相宗の僧。
sen.e: Bo GEN (? - July 15, 746) was a priest of Hosso sect of Buddhism during the Heian period.
Genbo (? - July 15, 746) was a priest of the Hosso sect of Buddhism during the Nara period.
sen.cmt: extra space/ wording/ article/ the translation of wrong era corrected
sen.e: Genbo (date of birth unknown - July 15, 746) was a priest of the Hosso sect of Buddhism, who lived in the Nara period.

sen.j: 俗姓は阿刀（あと）氏。
sen.e: His secular surname was `ATO`.
His secular surname was Ato.
His secular surname was Ato.

sen.j: 阿刀阿加布の子。
sen.e: He was the son of Ato no Akafu.
He was the son of ATO no Akafu.
He was the son of ATO no Akafu.

sen.j: 義淵に師事。
sen.e: He studied under GIEN.
He studied under Gien.
He studied under Gien.

sen.j: 遣唐使に学問僧として随行、入唐して智周に法相を学ぶ、在唐は18年に及ぶ。
sen.e: He accompanied the Japanese mission to T`ang China as a scholar monk where he learnt about the Hosso Sect from CHISSHU during his 18 year sojourn in China.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He accompanied kento-shi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) as a scholar monk where he learnt about the Hosso sect from Chishu during his 18 year sojourn in China.
sen.cmt: *I corrected the original japanese sentence edited by the translator, from 及び to 及ぶ.*punctuation/ capitals/ vocab*pronunciation corrected for 智周: reference: http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%99%BA%E5%91%A8
sen.e: He accompanied kento-shi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) as a scholar monk where he learnt about the Hosso sect from Chishu during his 18 year sojourn in China.

sen.j: その間当時の皇帝であった玄宗に才能を認められ、三品の位に準じて紫の袈裟の下賜を受けた。
sen.e: His talents were recognized by the Chinese emperor of that time, Xuan Zong (aka Genso 玄宗) who conferred upon him 3rd (Sanpin) rank and received a purple monk's robe.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His talents were recognized by the Chinese emperor of that time, Xuan Zong, and as an Imperial gift, a purple kesa (Buddhist stole) was granted according to his rank, Sanbon (third rank).
sen.cmt: *I took out " (aka Genso 玄宗）" as it is extra info.*extra space*later part, rewritten (translation mistake, pronunciation mistake and so on)*meaning and pronunciation of 三品: http://kotobank.jp/word/%E4%B8%89%E5%93%81
sen.e: His talents were recognized by the Chinese emperor of that time, Xuan Zong, and as an Imperial gift, a purple kesa (Buddhist stole) was granted according to his rank, Sanbon (third rank).

sen.j: 約20年後の次回の遣唐使に随い経論5000巻の一切経を携えて帰国。
sen.e: Approximately 20 years later her returned to Japan at the behest of the next Japanese mission to T`ang China bearing with him the complete (5000) Buddhist scripture scrolls.
Approximately 20 years later, by following the next kento-shi, he returned to Japan with the complete Buddhist scriptures of 5,000 scrolls of Kyoron (sutra repository and Abhidhamma-pitaka).
Approximately 20 years later, by following the next kento-shi, he returned to Japan with the complete Buddhist scriptures of 5,000 scrolls of Kyoron (sutra repository and Abhidhamma-pitaka).

sen.j: 封戸を与えられた。
sen.e: Introduced the Fuko system of public ownership of temples.
He was given fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples).
He was given fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples).

sen.j: 翌737年（天平9年）僧正に任じられて内道場（内裏において仏像を安置し仏教行事を行う建物）に入り、聖武天皇の母藤原宮子の病気を祈祷により回復させ賜物をうけた。
sen.e: Back in Japan, he was subsequently appointed as a high priest and entered the inner temple of the imperial palace (located inside the palace grounds where Buddhist sculptures were installed and religious services performed) where his prayers for Miyako FUJIWARA (mother of Emperor Shomu) resulted in her recovery.

In the following year of 737, he was appointed as a high priest and entered a naidojo (palace chapel, the space of which was reserved particularly for esoteric rituals and in which Buddhist sculptures were installed and religious services performed), where his prayers for FUJIWARA no Miyako (mother of Emperor Shomu) resulted in her recovery and a reward granted to him for that.
sen.cmt: 原文脱字を対応ウィキ・サイトに準じて修正のうえ再訳出しました。用語・形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: In the following year of 737, he was appointed as a high priest and entered a naidojo (palace chapel, the space of which was reserved particularly for esoteric rituals and in which Buddhist sculptures were installed and religious services performed), where his prayers for FUJIWARA no Miyako (mother of Emperor Shomu) resulted in her recovery and a reward granted to him for that.

sen.j: 聖武天皇の信頼も篤く、吉備真備とともに橘諸兄政権の担い手として出世したが、人格に対して人々の批判も強く、失敗したものの740年（天平12年）には藤原広嗣が玄昉を排除しようと九州で兵を起こした（藤原広嗣の乱）。
sen.e: He enjoyed the deep confidence of Emperor Shomu and was promoted for his contribution to the administration of Moroe TACHIBANA and Makibi KIBI however, people were critical of his personality and as a result of errors, Fujiwara No Hirotsugu mobilized troops in Kyushu for the ouster of Bo GEN (Fujiwara No Hirotsugu Revolt).

He enjoyed the deep confidence of Emperor Shomu and, together with KIBI no Makibi, was promoted for his contribution to the administration of TACHIBANA no Moroe, but people were critical of his personality, and in 740, Fujiwara no Hirotsugu mobilized troops in Kyushu for the ouster of Genbo, albeit unsuccessfully (the Rebellion of Fujiwara no Hirotsugu).
sen.cmt: 原文脱字を対応ウィキ・サイトに準じて修正のうえ再訳出しました。用語・誤訳・形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: He enjoyed the deep confidence of Emperor Shomu and, together with KIBI no Makibi, was promoted for his contribution to the administration of TACHIBANA no Moroe, but people were critical of his personality, and in 740, Fujiwara no Hirotsugu mobilized troops in Kyushu for the ouster of Genbo, albeit unsuccessfully (the Rebellion of Fujiwara no Hirotsugu).

sen.j: 翌741年（天平13年）千手経1000巻を書写供養している。
sen.e: Subsequently he transcribed 1000 scripture scrolls by hand.
In the following year of 741, he transcribed the Senju-kyo sutra of 1,000 scrolls by hand as a Buddhist rite.
sen.cmt: 原文脱字を対応ウィキ・サイトに準じて修正のうえ再訳出しました。用語・形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: In the following year of 741, he transcribed the Senju-kyo sutra of 1,000 scrolls by hand as a Buddhist rite.

sen.j: しかし、藤原仲麻呂が勢力を持つようになると、745年（天平17年）筑紫観世音寺別当に左遷、封物も没収され、翌746年（天平18年）任地で没した。
sen.e: However, with Fujiwara No Nakamaro`s increased influence, he was demoted to become head of Chikushi Kanzeon-ji Temple, his seals were also confiscated and he passed away at his next post.

However, with Fujiwara no Nakamaro's increased influence, he was demoted, in 745, to become betto (head) of Chikushi Kanzeon-ji Temple, his fubutsu (products of the fuko) were confiscated, and in the following year of 746, he passed away at his post.
sen.cmt: 原文脱字を対応ウィキ・サイトに準じて修正のうえ再訳出しました。用語・形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: However, with Fujiwara no Nakamaro's increased influence, he was demoted, in 745, to become betto (head) of Chikushi Kanzeon-ji Temple, his fubutsu (products of the fuko) were confiscated, and in the following year of 746, he passed away at his post.

sen.j: 玄昉に関しては奇怪な逸話が多い。
sen.e: There are many curious anecdotes about Bo GEN.
There are many bizarre anecdotes about Genbo.
sen.cmt: 表現・人名を修正しました
sen.e: There are many bizarre anecdotes about Genbo.

sen.j: まず史書である『続日本紀』の彼の卒伝に、「藤原広嗣が霊の為に害せらる」とあり、当時広嗣の怨霊によって彼が死んだとの考えがあったことが知られる。
sen.e: Firstly there is an obituary that appears in the 6 part Japanese historical tome 'Shoku Nihongi' where, it makes it known that it is thought that he died because the ghost of Fujiwara No Hirotsugu killed him in revenge for some offence towards Hirotsugu.
Firstly, there is an obituary that appears in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan), showing that he died because the ghost of Fujiwara no Hirotsugu holding a grudge against him killed him.
sen.cmt: 表現・形式を修正しました
sen.e: Firstly, there is an obituary that appears in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan), showing that he died because the ghost of Fujiwara no Hirotsugu holding a grudge against him killed him.

sen.j: これが後世の書物になると話があらぬ方向に広がっていく。
sen.e: For a tome written for posterity, the story takes an unthinkable twist.
In a book written by posterity, the story takes an unthinkable twist.
In a book written by posterity, the story takes an unthinkable twist.

sen.j: 『元亨釈書』には、空中から手があらわれて玄昉を連れ去り、後日、頭のみが興福寺に落ちており、これが広嗣の霊のせいであったという記事がある。
sen.e: In the book `Genko shakusho` (History of Buddhism of the Genko era) there are reports that a hand reached down from the heavens and snatched Bo GEN away and the next day just his head fell to earth at Kofuku-ji Temple: this being due to the ghost of Hirotsugu.

In the book "Genko shakusho" (History of Buddhism of the Genko Era) there are reports that a hand reached down from the heavens and snatched Genbo away and the next day just his head fell to earth at Kofuku-ji Temple, this being due to the ghost of Hirotsugu.

In the book "Genko shakusho" (History of Buddhism of the Genko Era) there are reports that a hand reached down from the heavens and snatched Genbo away and the next day just his head fell to earth at Kofuku-ji Temple, this being due to the ghost of Hirotsugu.

sen.j: 『元亨釈書』には、「藤室と通ず」（藤原氏の妻と関係を持った）とあり、これは藤原宮子のことと思われる。
sen.e: In the book `Genko shakusho` (History of Buddhism of the Genko era) there is mention of `asociating with Fujimuro' (having relations with a married lady of the Fujiwara clan) which is thought to refer to Miyako FUJIWARA.
The "Genko shakusho" indicates that '[Genbo] associated with Fujimuro (or Toshitsu)' (i.e. he had relations with a married lady of the Fujiwara clan), which is thought to refer to FUJIWARA no Miyako.
sen.cmt: 表現・用語・形式を修正しました
sen.e: The "Genko shakusho" indicates that '[Genbo] associated with Fujimuro (or Toshitsu)' (i.e. he had relations with a married lady of the Fujiwara clan), which is thought to refer to FUJIWARA no Miyako.

sen.j: 宮子との密通の話は『興福寺流記』『日本現報善悪霊異記』『七大寺年表』『扶桑略記』などにもみえる。
sen.e: Talk of Miyako`s adultery can also be seen in `Kofukuji ruki` (Records of Kofuku-ji Temple), Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryouiki), the `Chronicle of the Seven Temples` and `Fuso ryakki` (A Short History of Japan)".

Likewise, there is a mention of Genbo's adultery with Miyako in "Kofukuji ruki" (records of the Kofuku-ji Temple), "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (a set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the "Nihon Ryoiki"), the "Shichidaiji nenpyo" (literally, Chronicle of the Seven Temples) and "Fuso ryakki" (A Short History of Japan).

sen.e: Likewise, there is a mention of Genbo's adultery with Miyako in "Kofukuji ruki" (records of the Kofuku-ji Temple), "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (a set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the "Nihon Ryoiki"), the "Shichidaiji nenpyo" (literally, Chronicle of the Seven Temples) and "Fuso ryakki" (A Short History of Japan).

sen.j: 『今昔物語集』『源平盛衰記』には、光明皇后と密通し、それを広嗣に見咎められたことが乱の遠因になったとしている。
sen.e: In the `Konjaku Monogatarishu` collection and `Rise and Fall of the Genji & Heike` he apparently had an adulterous relationship with Empress Komyo which led to Hirotsugu finding fault and was the underlying cause of the conflict.

In "Konjaku monogatarishu" (The Konjaku Tales, which literally means the tales from the present and the past, referring to a 31-volume collection of stories written during the late Heian period) and "Genpei seisuiki" (Rise and Fall of the Genji and the Heike), he apparently had an adulterous relationship with Empress Komyo which led to Hirotsugu finding fault and was the underlying cause of the rebellion.

sen.j: もちろん、いずれも後世の史料であり信用する必然性はとぼしい。
sen.e: Of course, in either case these historical records are inevitably of dubious credence.
Of course, in either case these historical records written by posterity are inevitably of dubious credence.

sen.j: やはり早くから破戒僧と信じられていた道鏡と混同された形跡もみられる。
sen.e: It is also believed that without doubt from early on there is a case of mistaken identity with a sinful monk and fellow man of the cloth.
There is evidence of Genbo confused with Dokyo who is believed to have been a sinful monk from earlier on.
sen.cmt: 誤解釈につき再訳出しました
sen.e: There is evidence of Genbo confused with Dokyo who is believed to have been a sinful monk from earlier on.

sen.j: しかし、『日本霊異記』に早くも密通記事がみえていることからみて、玄昉の栄達が妬まれたことが分かる。
sen.e: However, in the early Buddhist texts `Nihon Ryouiki`, early accounts of adultery can be seen and, some were jealous of Bo GEN`s fame.

sen.e: However, based on the fact that the "Nihon Ryoiki" includes early accounts of adultery, it is clear that some were jealous of Genbo's fame.

sen.j: またそこに宮子との関係を想像したひともいたこと、さらには彼の没落と死去が広嗣の怨霊と結びつける理解のあったことは認められるだろう。
sen.e: Also, there were those who speculated over a relationship with Miyako and in addition, there were those who believed in a link between Bo GEN`s downfall and death with Hirotsugu`s revengeful ghost.
